title: Why is ketchup so hard to pour? - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What type of fluids respond to force linearly?

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes a thousand times thinner

options.label: B
options.text: It will remain the same thickness

options.label: C
options.text: It will become a thousand times thinner

options.label: D
options.text: The tomato particles will get smushed into little ellipses, allowing the ketchup to flow

options.label: C
options.text: The ketchup remains the same thickness

options.label: D
options.text: The water near the edges of the container serves as a lubricant, allowing the ketchup to flow

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden thickening at a threshold force, and sudden thinning after a small force is applied for a long time

options.label: D
options.text: Gradual thickening at a threshold force, and gradual thinning after a small force is applied for a long time

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: Why is ketchup one of the more complicated mixtures out there?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is made from tomatoes

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is made from water

options.label: C
